moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5: The opponent chooses to continue with the Quaade Gambit.
moves.4. Bc4 g4: The agressive Lolli Gambit (Wild Muzio Gambit)
moves.5. O-O: Here the two best options are 5. 0-0 or 5. Ne5.
moves.6. Qxf3 Qf6 7. e5: Between d3 and e5 I choose e5.
moves.7... Qxe5 8. Bxf7+:
Two options are acceptable here.
8. Bxf7+! (double Muzio Gambit)
or 
8. The less aggressive d3. (The engine prefers this move).

I choose the first.
moves.8... Kxf7 9. d4 Qxd4+: The databases favor Qf5 over Qxd4+ (although both are still just fine).
moves.10. Be3 Qxb2:
Qxb2?  Is a little too aggressive and ignores the pressure white is building up on the king side.
The more defensive Qg7 or even Qf6 have better outcomes for black.
moves.11... Nf6:
Nf6?  Another mistake. Qf6 would extend the game much longer.
Engine analysis suggests the following: … Qf6 12. Qxc7 Qxf1+ 13. Kxf1 Nc6 14. Qf4+ Nf6 15. Nc3 Be7 16. Nd5 Rg8 17. Nxe7 Nxe7 18. Bd4 Ned5 19. Qe5 Re8
moves.12. Bd4: 12. Bd4!  Attacks the queen and the knight.
moves.12... Bc5: The final mistake by the opponent.  The reason is a checkmate in 3 moves … Bc5 13. Qxf6+ Ke8 14. Re1+ Be7 15. Qxe7#
moves.13. Qxf6+ Ke8 14. Qf7+:
Here I was a little hasty.  I missed the checkmate in 2. (14. Re1+ Be7 15. Qxe7#).
In game I realized I missed it and could still perform a checkmate (14. Qf7+ Kd8
15. Qf6+ Ke8 16. Re8+ Be7 17. Qxe7#).

My opponent realizes this and resigns.
